And since March, all of his Mimolette shipments - about a ton of cheese - have been held up because of one small problem - one very small problem.
Well, if you look, like here, all you see, like the dust.

Cheese mites, which de Vitton is scraping off the rind of Mimolette, are microscopic bugs.
They're mostly a mild industry nuisance that are brushed off aged cheeses.
But for Mimolette, they're actually encouraged.
The Mimolette has been made this way since the 17th century, with the cheese mite eating the rind.
They really affect on the nuttiness of the taste.
When the cheese is done aging, the mites are removed.

They don't want to see more than six mites per square inch, which for Mimolette is an impossible standard.
They say the product because of the mites is not proper for human consumption.
